summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Arkansas today entered final judgments against Stanley Banks and Barbara Banks in a civil injunctive action brought by the SEC against the defendants.  The SEC's complaint alleges that the defendants violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the complaint, Stanley and Barbara had been married for twenty-four years and were engaged for eighteen months when the parties separated in 2015. The complaint further alleges that Stanley had worked for Shippers, Georgia Pacific, and Union Pacific during their marriage, and he had worked as a carpenter, truck driver, and truck driver.  As alleged in the SEC's Complaint, the defendants had a history of misappropriating funds from each of their spouses, and Stanley had been ordered to pay $'13,255.11 on his vehicle, despite her having stated that the debt had been paid with proceeds from the Fordyce Bank & Trust loan.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint in the complaint Stanley consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of Section 9-12-315 of the Exchange Act, and orders him to pay a civil penalty of $'14,172.56. The settlement is subject to court approval.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of New York today announced criminal charges against Stanley.  Among other things, the SEC is seeking a permanent injunction, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and civil money penalties.  On May 24, 2018, the U. S. District Judge in the Western District of North Carolina issued a temporary restraining order against Stanley from further violations of the federal securities laws, ordering him to surrender his passport, and imposing an officer-and-director bar against him from serving as an officer or director of a public company. The court also issued an order requiring the defendants to pay civil penalties in the amount of $2,095.32 per month for a period of forty-eight (48) months at which time the judge will determine whether to order Stanley to disgorge his ill health, pay alimony, and pay a $'12,000 civil penalty.  Stanley also agreed to be enjoined from associating with any broker, dealer, penny stock dealer, investment adviser, municipal securities dealer, or nationally recognized statistical rating organization, and to receive spousal support in the form of a $500,000 penalty.
